context: Brings back memories of my Navy days. In bad way. We had what we called pterodactyl airlines. Once we about hour before landing in New London Ct we hit rough turbulence. Plane got tossed 10,000 feet down in blink of eye. Captain came on with voice that sound like he was very calm and collected. Sorry folks hit batch of small turbulence there nothing to be scared about. Very reassuring. I was sitting right behind the pilots btw. I saw him reach for his coffee his hand was shaking so bad like he had just killed someone.  That's when I was like we must came really close to disaster.

replies.context: good captain. no points for scaring passengers by panicking
I served. I was in the cockpit of a cargo plane during landing . I thought the cockpit was going to smash into the runway.
I would've creamed my shorts.

It had top to it dude. It was Styrofoam cup not a typical coffee mug. Was held in one those dual little plastic cup holders the plane had on it.

There are no pilots available, let alone ones willing to fly old bottom feeder Lear 35's. 30 years ago, this was a fun plane to fly, You can't even get a training slot for many plane models, and when you do get a new type rating, in this case LR-jet, you probably aren't ready for what this plane offers. Experienced pilots won't work for the pay that this plane has attached to it. I have 9200 hours in Lear Jets, these and the model 45 and 60, and I cringe at who is allowed to fly these days before they are ready.

I grew up in Fallon, NV back when F4s were THE plane.  We weren't far from NAS Fallon, and I'd see them flying all the time.  Never understood why many people considered them ugly, I thought they were flying wonders.  It was pretty frequent to be in school, and "ka-boom," as in sonic boom, shook the whole classroom.  Pretty cool.

My son’s an IP in the T-38 Talon at Beale AFB. They’re beautiful little jets, but all are 50 - 60 years old and breakdown frequently. There’s a new trainer in the works that was supposed to be in service by 2023,  but with Milley at the helm it’ll be another decade. Wokeness takes precedence over safety.

I saw a Learjet 25 , a Canadian snow bird owner, overloaded with fuel , baggage, and passengers try to depart PSP ( Palm Springs )on a 85 degree day  and never achieve V2. All of the guys at the FBO came out to watch this fun and possible crash, but the pilots managed to get the aircraft stopped before it left the pavement. It was the first time I ever saw the emergency drag chute, thrust reversers, and a set of brakes burned out. The crew had to change their shorts after the excitement.
You get a lot of entertainment hanging out between flights.
